lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor said that the wife of the Nassau County executive, Edward P. Mangano, was charged in connection with a job that included working as a food taster at a restaurant.

byline.contributor: Vivian Yee and Arielle Dollinger contributed reporting.

headline.print_headline: The No-Show Job, a New York Tradition, Again Plays a Role in a Graft Case
headline.main: Once Again, a No-Show Job Plays a Role in a New York Graft Case

snippet: A federal prosecutor said that the wife of the Nassau County executive, Edward P. Mangano, was charged in connection with a job that included working as a food taster at a restaurant....
abstract: Indictment of Nassau County executive Edward P Mangano, his wife Linda Mangano and unnamed restaurateur highlights long tradition of 'no-show job,' in which someone is given paid position but not expected to work, in effort to funnel kickbacks and bribes; Linda Mangano had apparently been paid $450,000 over several years to work as food taster at one of restaurateur's businesses.
